author: PatientFaithlessness
body:
Hello fellow autists,

Many of you know me as the $DOCU preacher, who stuck his mighty COCKU into $DOCU last week and pulled out after massive 4x returns. (\~$40k in total profit). If your father's son is looking to wank himself off for the coming few months, I am presenting a new opportunity!

(*caution: This post will contain ideas that are for not suited for the faint in heart, but rather targeting autists who wish to earn a FUCKING PROFIT!)*

As many of you know, $WORK is, in essence, a replacement for email. It is a remote collaboration tool that allows people to effectively work together, access hundreds of thousands of critical applications and services, and find important information to do their best work. Last week they reported solid earnings, with Revenue jumped 50% from year-ago levels, and the company reported adding 12,000 new paying customers. More than 90,000 organizations signed on with Slack on either a paid or free plan during the three months ending April 30. The number of organizations paying $100,000 or more to Slack in annual recurring revenue rose by nearly half to 963. It also sees the good times continuing. The company projects full-year revenue growth of 36% to 38%.

Despite these solid reports, the company dropped 16%.

Investors in Slack should be proud of the company’s performance. According to management, the firm did extremely well in what was the first quarter of its 2021 fiscal year. Based on the data provided, revenue at the firm came in at $201.65 million. This represents a gain of 49.6% over the $134.82 million the firm generated the same quarter a year earlier. Such a high growth rate, particularly for a firm with a market capitalization of $22.4 billion before reporting the news, is difficult to come by. Currently the stock is severely undervalued and will probably rebound very quickly before hedge funds and smart money rebalance and pump this to the fucking moon. This morning Motley just posted two articles on $WORK, Investors Observer released improved price targets for $WORK, and the legendary David Hynes is asking you to get into a threesome and start Fucking $WORK in its ass!

[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/first-time-canaccord-buy-rating-231519661.html](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/first-time-canaccord-buy-rating-231519661.html)

Besides the fact that $WORK has plenty of room to consolidate growth with its SaaS potential, it's also beginning to form some monstrous partnerships with other tech giants like IBM and AMZN.

Positions:

8/21c $44. Cheap as tits and can only go up after being down 70% from last week.

author: BlindTreeFrog
body:
Buying Bitcoin is a gamble of faith that Bitcoin will have increased value at a future date.

Buying stock is either:  
1.  Belief that a company is worthwhile and something that one wants to own a piece of and possibly participate in voting/guidance of the company   
2.  Faith that dividend payouts will generate acceptable passive income  
3.  A gamble that someone believing any of these three points will come by later and pay more money than you did for the shares you want to sell  
(For small time investors who aren't buying respectable amounts of shares of companies and getting their names high on the "pay me out first" list which will add other ways to make money and more control of the company's direction)

If you only consider option 3 regarding stocks, there is no difference between buying BitCoin and buying Stocks; it's just a matter of which faith in the gamble being in your favor is stronger.

With Bitcoin, you are gambling purely on someone else being willing to gamble.  Yeah you can point to acceptance rates for payment services, but that hasn't penetrated enough to really be a factor outside of the true believers.

With stocks, you have the company to base actions on.  Pretend that  I bought 100 shares of IBM because I think they have good Research back in the early 2000's before Watson went on Jeopardy.  After Jeopardy the public demonstration doesn't change anything about the shares I own, but it caused people to want to buy shares of IBM; whatever reason they had didn't matter because it meant I could sell for an increased value.   And (in theory) I can see that cause an effect if I watch what the company is doing.  Everytime? No;  The market isn't that rational.   But could I see it more often then with bitcoin or straight chance?  Likely.

author: beta-one
body:
Hey - great questions so let me shed some light.

Most of these big companies rely on reseller models as they don't have the capacity to go after SMBs. Your point is spot on - CTS goes after small and medium size enterprises while IBM will go after the Fortune 500. It is purely a reseller model...but the company's main focus is converting these clients into more software. 

A lot of the targets they acquire are usually product specific - they end up selling a ton of Cisco or a ton of Dell without much overlap. But if they are selling Cisco, it's not as if their clients aren't buying Dell products also. That's the value prop that they pitch when they acquire targets - we are going to give you the tools to sell everything your clients want and need and your clients will love that they will not have multiple vendors. So effectively cross-selling is a huge selling point for the targets. 

With respect to Red Hat, IBM is actually giving Converge market development funds to pursue these markets effectively throwing their full weight behind them. 

And yes, 700m and still on the Venture...not something you see every day. I am pretty confident they will uplist to the TSX within the year and will aim to go after NASDAQ later this year if not early next year.

author: DukePhil
body:
How does this technology reseller model work; they license/resell solutions from Dell, IBM, etc... as in a contractor? Yet at the same time, compete directly with Dell, IBM, etc...when they're bidding on new business?

Or does CTS focus on smaller companies and their budgets, while IBM deals with the Fortune 500?

Not trying to poke holes in the thesis, just trying to understand this business model.

Side note - did almost CAD 700 mil in revenue for FY2019...and still on the TSX Venture?! Wow.

Appreciate the write-up on this relatively unknown play. Nice change from the usual CAPREIT, RioCan, big banks, etc... that we see here...

author: acidtrip76
body:
Acquiring company usually pays a premium on the stock price.  A couple of examples:

 Amazon paid $42 per share in an all-cash deal for whole foods which included debt. **The premium paid was \~27% to whole foods closing price** on Thursday, June 15 

&#x200B;

When IBM Acquired Red hat " The company, which won approval for the purchase from U.S. regulators in May and European Union regulators in late June, agreed to pay $190 a share for Red Hat, representing a **63 percent premium.** "

this reallocation you refer to has already happened and is continuing to happen, but there is a limit to it. Microsoft and Apple are not going to take over the world. At one time, it seemed like AOL and IBM would rule the world. Things change, companies fall, things get reorganized. Never assume that the current mega-caps will always be there.

author: tysonsmithshootname
body:
You make great points, and I hope you are right, brother! My livelihood depends on it lol.

I absolutely agree people will be seeking direct human contact. But that can be achieved without hotels. If 80% of attendees want to go to a conference, the 20% who are afraid are being heard by the Group contacts and travel planners. That will ease over time, but it may take half a decade (like we saw after the Recession) for group contribution to get back to normal percentages. 

As it relates to hotels, the issue isn't as much the individual traveler as much as companies cutting travel requirements out of budgets and putting mandates to hold meetings virtually. Or consolidating quarterly events into an annual event. Or let's say companies send less ppl to trade shows/conventions from their contingencies. Or even a company like IBM mandating a 25% travel reduction would have a major ripple effect throughout the industry. 

Leisure travel alone won't cut it for most markets. Even a low to moderate negative shift in corporate travel behavior will be beaten up badly. I believe 85% of travelers will return, but profitability will be inconsistent at best for the next 3 to 5 years.

author: CarrollPete
body:
> Diginex to be the largest US blockchain provider

By what metric? And this could only be remotely true in the context of a 100% blockchain focused company. IBM alone [employs 2,000+ blockchain experts, and counts Ford, Maersk, and the US FDA among it's current customers](https://www.ciodive.com/news/ibm-blockchain-cloud-revenue-jerry-cuomo/572037/). They project 10.6B in blockchain-related revenue by 2023.

There is a huge amount of competition in the space from non-US / non-publicly traded companies like ConsenSys. Look at some of their clients.

Anyone considering investing should do a lot of research in "blockchain as a service" companies beforehand. It is a very crowded space. Or look at [their services page](https://www.diginex.com/offerings/) and ask yourself if you're even sure what their value proposition is?

author: yura37
body:
Ok fair, your post died but you were asking something about what to buy. Best advice would actually be to wait a bit. Lots of people betting both red and green, hence the kangaroo memes. If you don't want to, there's a few options. With high IV spikes you can try iron condors to make money off the volatility. Otherwise buying stock and selling calls is more safe and you make money if the market goes up or stays the same, and cover a large part of losses if it goes down. If you are bullish hit the NASDAQ (qqq) if you are bearish hit spy. Stocks I would look into include ttd for large options premium, ba/ko/ibm/wm/wmt/oil(apa,fang,mro,mpc,xom) for dividend and long term growth, lulu for legging juice, wtrh for the delivery memes, and adbe/rh/docu/mdb/ayx for strong individuals. You might also consider the classic cows of msft appl amzm and fb. If you're going to put in decent money for gods sake hedge out with some gld for the coming inflation. 

Full disclosure I got like 70% of my equity in qqq calls because I'm expecting giant green dildos. Kinda like what you take but imagine them encrusted with big ass emeralds. Cheers and good luck.

author: cityoflostwages

author: ReyesA1991
body:
The only ones I have are Crown Castle and American Tower.

I wouldn't put all your eggs in 5G. You should go back and see how some of these companies fared under 4G.  Ericsson is cheaper today than when they were leaders in 4G development a decado ago. Qualcomm has increased 25% in the past 8 years, far underperforming the market.

You could have bought Qualcomm at their 2014 peak at $80. Or you could have bought in 2020 at $84. 6 years for 5% return is awful.

And the biggest loser is Nokia, which has gone down 50% since 2009 yet is somehow still a darling.

A lot of these companies are like IBM: bereft of innovation and their best days have passed. I wouldn't let the 5G shiny ball distract you from lifting up the hood.

author: el333
body:
> Tech companies like MSFT are too risky if you think of companies like IBM.

Funny that you say that. Around 1999-2001 when I was too young to want to spend all my allowance on food/video games my dad suggested that I invest it in some stocks. He said tech would be big going forward and listed off some options which we narrowed down to MSFT, AAPL, and IBM. I obviously didn't know any better and just random picked IBM, ultimately put in about $1500 of allowance money.

I recently remembered this play 20 years later when someone mentioned IBM and was talking to my dad about how I literally picked the worst option as the share price hasn't moved in 20 years. My dad showed me the statement (never sold) and turns out I'm still at about 100% returns just from DRIP! Sure it's not 8x+ return from MSFT or 300x+ from AAPL (if only...) but still much better than holding in cash or spending on maplestory items

author: peter-doubt
body:
If a company like IBM has an international presence, it's traded here *and* overseas. London (and Frankfurt) are 5+ hours ahead of NY. That's the basis of a premarket. 

The NYSE has facilities that participate, as do individual brokerages. 

Low volume?  Not necessarily.

author: myNameIsPDT
body: I like them conceptually, but I'm not sold on any one material as the "ideal" qubit at the moment. Room temp superposition and existing nano scale fabrication methods are appealing for silicon, but there is still a lack of ability to sustain superposition for a meaningful amount of time. From an investment standpoint, I don't like pure quantum investments because the field is still up in the air with no clear direction. I also, don't like investing in foreign stocks because they aren't listed on US exchanges and OTC foreign markets have poor liquidity. The reason I really like QUBT is because their software can run on GPUs and CPUs, so they have a market now. Solving increasingly complex NP style questions is needed. I think QUBT is probably the only way to get high exposure to quantum, while still investing in a company with upside unrelated to quantum... aside from google, IBM, and intel of course.

author: w1na
body:
She did a good job, no one could even imagine even 5 years ago where AMD would be today.
When she took office, the cupboard were bare, there was no sales, no good architecture, losing for 2 decade to intel. Since the first athlon x64, they kept releasing bad products most of the time. In just 3 years, she made AMD go from Zero to Hero!

AMD now trading at tremendous numbers, no one thought would be possible ever. Heck just look 7 years back, the share price was about 2 bucks.

If there is any CEO who you feel should earn so much, it’s not people from Moderna, but Lisa Su.

Just to give you an idea, back in 2014 or so, I remember trying to buy AMD shares under 2 euros each (I wanted to get 2000 euro), before the order went through, it asked me for some paperwork confirmation, I then did not go through with the order and never did.

Missed on 1000 shares from AMD. I did not believe back then, although I saw it was incredibly cheap.

author: mechtech
body:
Well this is /r/investing, so buy quality and hold, diversify (beyond just bonds which may or may not have a good future in a zero rate world), and have worldwide exposure/don't arbitrarily lock yourself to your own country.

I actively trade, but in all likelihood in 2040 the investors at the top will likely have stories like "As Waymo got bigger, my ETF kept buying more, and now Waymo is 10 trillion dollars. And as that Chinese electric car company grew and took 1/3 of the 1 billion person Chinese market, my ETF kept buying more on the way up."

Although in that same vein, getting ahead of the tech curve might be one of the few ways for someone outside of the professional investor/institutional world to realistically get ahead. The trick is having the fortitude to hold for 1-2 decades. The financial crisis in '08 blew me out of so many hilariously good positions, like SBAC because the iPhone was just invented and 3G means more cell phone towers... It's not always rocket science. Anyone with some specialized insight into the future, whatever it may be, should consider putting a small well thought out speculative position on and leave it be. Small enough to not hurt if it goes nowhere, but big enough to care enough to check up and manage every few months.

Wow, just looked up an email from over 10 years ago. These names are probably in the mainstream investing language now, but wow... 10-100x if they were held. And it wasn't complex quant investing or anything, just looking ahead, positioning, and waiting.

Quotes from the email circa 10 years ago: "NVDA... They are also making a leap into scientific computing, where there's a lot of money to be made. They're the first major player to enter that arena to fight Intel and AMD in a long time, and their architecture is much more suited to scientific computing than the traditional CPUs that currently rule the top 100 supercomputer list. I think I'll see how that works out before selling NVDA"

"I might want to put some money in AMD as well. They're here to stay and may still be undervalued..."

"Universal Display Corp and LG Display (PANL/LPL) are also the leaders and partners in OLED screen development, which is bound to catch on eventually. Lower power use and much better image quality mean that it's just a matter of time before more devices adopt this new display technology and it becomes a new standard. I actually expect Apple to eventually partner up with LG (I think LG is their main LCD supplier) and use and use an OLED display on either a new product or a new Iphone version, which will kick OLED production into overdrive."

Food for thought... MicroLED is likely going to grow 1000x over the coming decades. AR and LIDAR sensors for AR will probably not just be used for face unlock and will get some killer apps, the next Snapchat or TikTok might be AR based. Self-Driving is going to be powered by thousands of companies, not just NVIDIA and Waymo. Quantum computing? AI providers in the military contracting space? Clean cargo ship tech to get in front of green regulations? It's endless, and so many people know about these little niches of information that very few others do. Even mundane spaces see world changing innovation every day. Getting in front of a curve is inherently speculative but it is also entertaining, educational to follow through development, and can be extremely profitable.

That's my appeal for pulling a few pennies out of the ETF pile and doing some a little different, especially if you have a "wheelhouse" that you know a little bit more about.

And aside from that, you know these are not gonna be large companies because they won’t be categorizing it as “companies with 10+” employees. That’s like using inches to measure a mile. 
I’d bet a majority of those companies have under 10 hosts.

author: p_giggles
body:
I'd say that because companies which are heavily shorted are often smaller companies, there isn't a lot of other (non-financial) recognition. So if people can't find much besides a "short the shit out of this company" report, it might be more important for management to attempt to keep the stock afloat, whether it's in their own self interest or not.

If you try to short Intel it's a bit of a different story considering there are 40 analysts covering it and an ungodly amount of brand recognition. If one analyst comes out with a short and 39 say Intel is fine, it's unlikely the short piece actually does anything. But if you have three analysts covering you, which is very common for small-cap companies, one short piece can actually fuck your shit up. 

Also since companies often use their equity as collateral for a loan, the higher stock price could afford more reasonable loan terms, which could help the company's actual business.

When Jim Keller goes to work somewhere, you know that in 2-3 years that company will be cranking out new game changing products. Apple / AMD / Tesla.

Jim joined Intel in 2018 after leaving Tesla. Presumably to help Intel get their shit together. I'd anticipate we'll see Intel come roaring back starting in 2021.

Jim coordinates chip makers into a well oiled machine. 

Hopefully AMD's architecture and practices that Jim left in place have legs to keep up with whatever Intel develops.

> Now why the fuck exactly would any company that’s not the size of intel, Apple, ibm etc need 150 hosts??? 

There are plenty of enterprise SaaS companies that have more than 150 sales people that aren't anywhere near the size of IBM, much less Apple. If every sales guy can host a Zoom call to talk to a prospective client, that's a host right there.

Why would you assume Zoom hosts are only for people internal to the company?

author: Shaun80
body: Some sectors are booming because of the pandemic and have huge growth potential when we emerge into our new normal post pandemic. This is especially true for technology allowing remote entertainment, medicine , commerce, payment and communication.  Netflix, E-commerce (Amazon,Shop) , Zoom video conferencing, cloud computing  (MSFT, Veev, Crm,fsly) , AI robotics (NVIDiA ,TSLA,TWLO, GOOG), 5G technology, semiconductors (AMD,TSM, QCOM, INTC) fintech (Square, Paypal, MA ,V), telemedicine (TDOC)   Brick and mortar retailers,oil , resources , REITs, financial sector will all take a hit when the economy opens to the new normal.
